verses.text: "Where has your beloved gone, O most beautiful among women? Where has your beloved turned, that we may seek him with you?"
verses.comment: The daughters of Jerusalem address the bride, showing concern for her separation from the beloved, echoing themes of communal seeking and the restoration of union.

verses.text: "My beloved has gone down to his garden, to the beds of spices, to graze among the lilies."
verses.comment: The bride knows where her beloved is, affirming intimate knowledge and closeness, a symbolic description of the union between Christ and the soul (cf. Song 2:16).

verses.text: "I am my beloved’s and my beloved is mine; he grazes among the lilies."
verses.comment: This profound mutual belonging prefigures the unity between Christ and the Church, rooted in love and mutual indwelling (see John 17:21-23).

verses.text: "You are beautiful as Tirzah, my love, pleasing as Jerusalem, awe-inspiring as an army with banners."
verses.comment: The beloved compares the bride to revered cities, highlighting her role as a gathering place for God's people radiant with glory.

verses.text: "Turn your eyes away from me, for they overwhelm me. Your hair is like a flock of goats leaping down the slopes of Gilead."
verses.comment: The lover is overwhelmed by the bride’s beauty; poetic repetition from earlier passages emphasizes lasting admiration.

verses.text: "Your teeth are like a flock of ewes coming up from the washing—each one has a twin; not one is missing."
verses.comment: Imagery of purity and completeness, again echoing earlier lines; such repetition reflects the constancy and holiness of the bride.

verses.text: "Your cheeks behind your veil are like halves of a pomegranate."
verses.comment: Fresh, vibrant beauty is highlighted here. Pomegranates often symbolized fullness and fruitfulness in ancient Israel's worship.

verses.text: "There are sixty queens and eighty concubines, and maidens without number."
verses.comment: The abundance of women points to both the grandeur of the king and the exclusivity of the bride, representing the chosen people among all nations.

verses.text: "But my dove, my perfect one, is unique; she is her mother’s only daughter, the pure favorite of her who bore her. Maidens saw her and called her blessed; queens and concubines praised her."
verses.comment: The singularity and purity of the bride draw echoes of the one chosen vessel bearing Christ (see Luke 1:28), presenting her as the fulfillment of Israel’s hope.

verses.text: "Who is this who appears like the dawn, fair as the moon, bright as the sun, awe-inspiring as an army with banners?"
verses.comment: The bride is depicted with pictures of light and power, prefiguring the adorned and glorious Church, and resembling the woman clothed with the sun in Revelation 12.

verses.text: "I went down to the walnut grove to see the green plants of the valley, to see if the vines had budded, if the pomegranates were in blossom."
verses.comment: A return to the garden setting signals growth and spiritual renewal; the imagery suggests the vigilance in searching for signs of spiritual fruit.

verses.text: "Before I was aware, my soul set me among the chariots of my noble people."
verses.comment: Sudden elevation and movement among the chariots shows a transformation and calling, symbolizing the soul lifted to fellowship with the elect.

verses.text: "Return, return, O Shulammite; return, return, that we may gaze upon you. Why should you gaze upon the Shulammite, as upon the dance before two armies?"
verses.comment: The repeated call reflects longing for the bride and admiration of her splendor. Her dance is mysterious and awe-inspiring, illustrating the Church’s ongoing role in salvation history.
